A simple and scalable impregnation–calcination–washing (ICW) method has been proposed for synthesizing PtSn/MFI catalysts. This study primarily investigates the impact of zeolite acidity, the order of preparation steps, and the influence of tin, NaCl, and water washing on the characteristics of ICW propane dehydrogenation catalysts. To improve the dispersion of Pt and Sn, a zeolite characterized by high external surface acidity was used as a support. In addition, a significant quantity of NaCl was employed during the impregnation process. Washing the zeolite surface to remove excess NaCl releases active sites and redistributes Pt. This preparation procedure resulted in the formation of highly active and stable propane dehydrogenation catalysts. The most efficient PtSn/MFI ICW catalyst exhibited an initial propane conversion of 36%, propylene selectivity of 96%, and a deactivation constant of 0.009 h−1 at 570 °C, with a weight hourly space velocity of 28 h−1. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Propane dehydrogenation Zeolite PtSn/MFI ICW method Washing Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene, a vital raw material for producing polymers, propylene oxide, alcohols, acrylonitrile, epoxy resins, and propylene glycol, has an annual global production exceeding 100 million tons, with a continuing upward trend [1]. Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) presents an alternative to the conventional pyrolysis and catalytic cracking methods for propylene production [2,3]. However, under harsh reaction conditions, rapid coke formation and sintering of the active phase are almost inevitable. Consequently, extensive research has been directed toward the development of active and stable PDH catalysts. Catalysts based on Pt, CrOx, GaOx, and VOx have garnered significant interest [4,5]. Pt-based heterogeneous systems are the most active catalysts for the PDH reaction [6]. The catalyst performance is influenced by various factors, including the nature of the support, the presence of promoters, the method of metal introduction, and post-treatment conditions. A uniform distribution of the active metal and promoters on the support surface, along with a small size of metal particles, is crucial for achieving an active and stable propane dehydrogenation catalyst [7,8]. The performance of Pt catalysts is significantly improved by adding a promoter such as Sn, Ga, In, Zn, Cu, or Ce [9–14]. These promoters enhance Pt dispersion, bolster catalyst stability, and alter the Pt chemical state, affecting selectivity [15]. Sn is the most common promoter in Pt-based PDH catalysts because of its positive effects on propylene selectivity and catalytic deactivation. Consequently, Sn frequently serves as a promoter in many industrial platinum-based catalysts [16]. The Pt–Sn catalytic system, which has been extensively investigated, demonstrates that both geometric and electronic effects contribute to the enhanced performance of the catalysts [17]. Numerous efforts have been made to develop active and stable Pt–Sn dehydrogenation catalysts. Studies have explored the impact of support and synthesis methods on the efficacy of Sn-promoted Pt PDH catalysts [18–23]. Moreover, calcination temperatures in air and hydrogen, the sequence of metal introduction, and the loadings of Sn and Pt have been identified as essential factors influencing catalyst performance [24–28]. Zeolites, with their regular porous structure, heat resistance, and acid sites that interact with active metals and promoters, are promising supports for dehydrogenation catalysts [29–32]. MFI-type zeolite has demonstrated effectiveness as a support for these catalysts [33–35]; however, enhancing the resistance to deactivation of MFI zeolite PDH catalysts remains a challenge. In addition, developing a simple and scalable method for the preparation of SnPt/MFI catalysts, which exhibit high Pt dispersion and improved catalytic performance, is another significant challenge. Recently, it was discovered that the distribution of Pt on the MFI zeolite surface significantly improves when both the platinum precursor and a large quantity of NaCl are introduced into the zeolite via impregnation. Following calcination, which fixes at least a portion of the active components in an insoluble form, the surplus inert salt can be removed by washing with water [36]. The excess NaCl not only assists in enhanced Pt dispersion but also effectively neutralizes the zeolite’s strong acidic sites. This enables the use of silica-alumina zeolites as a support for the preparation of active and stable PDH reaction catalysts. This method, termed impregnation–calcination–washing (ICW), modifies the conventional incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) approach. Previously, PtSn/MFI propane dehydrogenation catalysts had not been obtained using the ICW method. In this study, ICW PtSn/MFI catalysts were prepared using MFI zeolites with varying acidity levels and impregnated with different amounts of H2PtCl6, SnCl2, and NaCl. The influence of the sequence of metal introduction and the washing process were also investigated. The catalytic properties of the resultant samples were thoroughly examined and are discussed herein. 2 Experimental section In this work, given the extensive study of PtSn/MFI systems, optimal parameters from existing literature were employed. For example, a calcination temperature of 500 °C is identified as optimal for processing both intermediate products and final catalysts [24]. Furthermore, the commonly used platinum and tin precursors, H2PtCl6 and SnCl2, were selected. NaCl was also used as an effective Pt dispersant in the ICW method. 2.1 Materials MFI-type zeolites with SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratios of 50, 80, 280, and 716 in the NH4-form were procured from Zeolyst International. These were used without prior calcination. NaCl, SnCl2 * 2 H2O, and H2PtCl6 * 6 H2O were of analytical grade. Propane with a purity of 99.92% was obtained from BK Group, Russia. 2.2 Catalysts preparation Catalysts were prepared using the following general procedures: • Impregnation was performed using the IWI method. The impregnated zeolite powder was maintained for 1 h with periodic stirring at 70 °C. Subsequently, the product was dried at 150 °C for 1 h. • Calcination occurred in air within a muffle furnace at a heating rate of 10 °C/min to reach 500 °C. The sample remained at this temperature for 1 h. • The washing process involved treating the calcined sample with distilled water at a volume five times the sample weight. This was conducted with magnetic stirring at 80 °C for 1 h. Afterward, the product was filtered without further washing and was dried at 150 °C for 1 h. In the prepared samples, designated as (xNaySn)(zPt)w, x, y, and z represent the nominal weight percentages of Na, Sn, and Pt, respectively. The presence of more than one metal in parentheses indicates their co-impregnation. The letter “w” denotes the washing procedure. Each impregnation or washing step was succeeded by calcination. The initial MFI zeolites are referred to as MFI-M, with “M” indicating the M = SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio. Unless stated otherwise, the nominal amount of Pt and Sn were 0.5 wt% and 1.0 wt%, respectively, and MFI-80 was used as the initial zeolite. A detailed procedure for preparing the (3NaSn)(Pt)w catalyst, as an example, is provided in the Supplementary Information. 2.3 Catalytic experiments Catalytic experiments were conducted in a quartz tubular reactor (ID = 10 mm) at atmospheric pressure. The sample powder was pelletized and crushed to a 0.5–1.1 mm fraction. Between two quartz wool beds in the reactor, 0.05–0.4 g of catalyst was loaded and heated to 570 °C under a 15 ml/min H2 flow, increasing at a rate of 10 °C/min, and maintained at 570 °C for 1 h before catalytic evaluation. Subsequently, the H2 was replaced with a propane flow of 13 ml/min. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) varied from 3.5 to 28 h−1, achieved by adjusting the catalyst loading. Unless stated otherwise, PDH reactions were conducted using pure propane, without hydrogen or inert gas. Reaction products were analyzed online using a Chromatec Crystal-5000 gas chromatograph equipped with a 25-m polytrimethylsilyl acetylene capillary column and a flame ionization detector. Catalyst regeneration was conducted by employing a 10% O2 in N2 flow at a rate of 20 ml/min for 1 h at 500 °C. Afterward, the catalyst was reduced in a stream of pure hydrogen (20 ml/min) for 1 h at 570 °C. The propane conversions and reaction product selectivity were determined using the following equations: Propane conversion: X = mass of propane in the feed − mass of propane in the product mass of propane in the feed * 100 % ; Product selectivity: S i = mass of product i mass of all products * 100 % ; Product yield: Y i = S i * X / 100 The definition of specific activity is as follows: the amount of propylene produced, measured in moles, per mole of Pt atoms per second. The deactivation constants, denoted as K d were derived using the following equation: ( 1 − X f ) / X f ( 1 − X in ) / X in = e K d * t , where. t - time on stream;. Xin denotes the propane conversion after 1 h on stream;. Xf denotes the propane conversion at the end of the experiment. A higher deactivation constant signifies an accelerated reduction in the catalyst activity. 2.4 Catalyst characterization The surface area of the samples was analyzed using low-temperature nitrogen adsorption (Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument). We employed the BET method for evaluating the surface area; the analysis demonstrated reproducibility of ± 3% of the measured value. We evaluated the state of platinum on the catalyst surface through XPS analysis. XPS spectra were obtained using an Axis Ultra DLD (Kratos Analytical Ltd) spectrometer, using Al Kα X-rays (hν = 1486.7 eV). To record high-resolution spectra, the transmission energy was set at 40 eV. The binding energies were calibrated on a scale where EB (C1 s) = 285.0 eV, referencing adventitious carbon. Elemental analysis was quantitatively conducted using energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy on a Thermo Scientific ARL Perform’x instrument. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was used for acidity evaluation (UNISIT USGA-101 chemisorption analyzer). The samples were initially saturated with NH3 at 60 °C for 15 min, followed by purging in a He flow at 100 °C. The NH3–TPD experiments were performed in a He flow (30 ml/min) with a heating rate of 8°/min. The released NH3 was detected using a thermal conductivity detector. The coke content on the samples post-catalytic experiments was quantified using thermogravimetric analysis (Instruments SDT Q600 equipment). This quantification relied on measuring the weight loss of the samples in an air flow within a temperature range of 300 °C–600 °C. In addition, the phase composition of the samples was analyzed using powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a TongDa TD-3700 diffractometer equipped with CuKα radiation. The crystal size and morphology of the initial zeolite were examined using a Hitachi TM3030 scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The size distribution of platinum particles was observed through transmission electron microscopy (TEM), using both FEI Osiris and JEOL JEM2100 UHR instruments. These instruments have sources with a field emission of 200 keV. We assumed the equivalent diameter of a particle to be the diameter of a circle with the same area as the particle. We derived particle size distribution diagrams by analyzing and summarizing calculations from 7 images of the corresponding samples, processing the sizes of over 1000 particles. We then calculated the mean diameters of these particles as D ̅ = ∑ D i 2 / ∑ D i . 2.4.1 CO chemisorption experiments The process for determining the dispersion of Pt was conducted applying a CO pulse chemisorption method, using a UNISIT USGA-101 chemisorption analyzer. Approximately 200 mg of the sample was placed in a quartz microreactor with an inner diameter of 4 mm. This setup was then heated to 200 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under a He flow of 10 ml/min, and maintained at 200 °C for 0.5 h. Subsequently, the gas flow was switched from He to H2, and the sample was further heated to 570 °C at the same rate under an H2 flow at 10 °C/min. This temperature was maintained for another 30 min. After this, the reactor was cooled back down to 200 °C under the H2 flow, then flushed with He at 200 °C for 30 min, and finally cooled to room temperature under a continuous He flow. For the chemisorption analysis, 0.25 ml pulses of carbon monoxide (CO), diluted to 9.7% in He, were introduced into the He stream at 3-min intervals. This process was continued until the chemisorption sites reached saturation. The CO concentration in the reactor’s effluent was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The quantity of CO chemisorbed was calculated based on the areas of the TCD signals. The dispersion of Pt denoted as D, was determined using the following equation D = V * AW * SF W * 22414 * 100 % , Where “V” represents the volume of the adsorbed CO (ml), AW denotes the atomic weight of Pt (g*mol−1), SF denotes the stoichiometry factor (with SF assumed to be 1), and W denotes the weight of Pt in the catalyst (g). 2.4.2 IR-CO experiments IR spectroscopy was used to study the interaction of platinum with CO, specifically on a Nicolet Protégé 460 spectrometer. This device features an optical resolution of 4 cm−1 and is within a range of 4000–400 cm−1. Experiments were conducted in a vacuum IR cell. The samples, shaped into disks with a diameter of 1.6 cm, ρ of ∼10 mg/cm2 were first reduced in the IR cell at a 450 °C for 1 h, followed by a 30-min evacuation period and subsequent cooling. For CO adsorption, measured volumes were introduced at room temperature until an equilibrium CO pressure of 1 Torr was reached. IR spectra were recorded under these conditions as well. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Influence of zeolite acidity The textural, acidic properties, and chemical composition of the parent MFI-716 zeolite are presented in Figs. S1–S3 and Table S1. This is in conjunction with the properties of MFI-50, MFI-80, and MFI-280 zeolites, as described in our previous work [36]. The acidity levels of the initial zeolites were determined using TPD of ammonia and IR spectroscopy of absorbed pyridine. (Figs. S2 and S3). It is important to neutralize the acidity of zeolites with a large number of acid sites when they are used as a support to inhibit side reactions. Therefore, zeolites with few or no acid sites are typically chosen for synthesizing PDH catalysts. The ICW method is an effective and convenient approach for reducing the acidity of zeolites, enabling the use of those with low silicon dioxide/aluminum oxide SiO2/Al2O3 ratios in the PDH process. Furthermore, a high concentration of acid sites, particularly on the external surface of the zeolite crystals, is preferred for creating stable catalysts using the ICW method [36]. Neutralizing the support’s acidity with alkali metals is known to improve selectivity in the PDH reaction [37,38]. This reduction in acidity helps suppress side reactions, including cracking, oligomerization, and aromatization. With respect to zeolites, an optimal concentration of Na is advantageous for the reaction, and it is crucial to strictly control the Na content [39]. Both acid sites and excess NaCl contribute to the dispersion of Pt during the preparation of NaPt/MFI catalysts using the ICW method [36]. In this study, we selected the following sequence for introducing the metals. First, we impregnated the zeolite with a mixture of SnCl2 and NaCl. Next, we further impregnated it with H2PtCl6, followed by washing it with water. Calcinations were performed after each step of these procedures. In this process, we anticipated that initially, the zeolite’s acidity would aid in dispersing tin. This dispersion would likely result from the ion-exchange reaction between SnCl2 and the zeolite’s acidic sites, as well as the dilution effect of SnCl2 with NaCl. In the following step, the excess NaCl was expected to dissolve in the impregnating solution, leading to a co-impregnation with a mixture of H2PtCl6 and NaCl. In this scenario, the enhanced dispersion of Pt is expected due to the geometric influence of the previously dispersed tin and the dilution effect of H2PtCl6 with NaCl. According to the ICW method, co-impregnation of the Pt precursor with an excess of NaCl has been shown to improve Pt dispersion [36]. The (PtSn) catalyst, derived from MFI-80 without Na addition, exhibited high initial activity but low stability and selectivity, as seen in Table 1, sample 1. Selectivities approximately 35% for C1-C2 hydrocarbons and 40–46% for aromatic compounds during the PDH reaction were attributed to the large number of acid sites, which are responsible for the cracking and aromatization of propane and propylene. The theoretical amount of Na required to neutralize the acid sites in the MFI-80 zeolite is approximately 1 wt%. Introducing 1.4 wt% of Na into the (1.4NaSn)(Pt) sample resulted in an immediate increase in propylene selectivity and yield, as indicated in Table 1, sample 2. Nonetheless, even with the addition of 40% excess NaCl, the initial propylene selectivity remained below 90%, suggesting that some acid sites remained active due to uneven NaCl distribution on the zeolite surface. Raising the Na content from 1.4% to 4% improved selectivity to 95–96%, but it decreased the stability of the IWI catalysts in the PDH reaction ( Fig. 1a). This observation aligns with previous studies on PtSn/MFI [39] and PtSnNa@SUZ-4 [40] catalysts. Transitioning from IWI to ICW samples, the excess NaCl and Pt-containing compounds are further redistributed on the zeolite surface during the water-washing process [36]. The washing of IWI samples 2–5 (Table 1) led to the preparation of ICW samples 6–10, respectively, with higher stability (Fig. 1b). Specifically, after washing the (1.4NaSn)(Pt) sample, Na content decreased from 1.45% to 1.13%, and the initial selectivity increased from 88.5% to 92.5%. This indicates the removal of excess NaCl and the redistribution of Na+ during washing, contributing to further neutralization of acidic centers. In addition, the Pt content concentration decreased from 0.49% to 0.37%, and the Cl level dropped from 0.56% to 0.15%. The simultaneous rise in Pt dispersion from 11% to 15% is attributable to the release of Pt sites previously bound to Cl and Pt redistribution throughout the washing phase. Washing IWI samples 2–5 significantly improves their stability, as observed in samples 6–9, a common outcome of the ICW method. For both the unwashed (1.8NaSn)(Pt) and washed (1.8NaSn)(Pt)w samples, the deactivation constants are similar; however, the stability of propylene yield is notably better in the washed samples. The distinction between IWI and ICW samples becomes more pronounced when a higher Na concentration (3–4%) is used in the impregnation process (Fig. 1a and b). Although the efficacy of ICW catalysts is marginally influenced by the initial Na content, a concentration of 2–3 wt% Na is optimal for MFI-80-derived catalysts (Fig. 1c). Despite the good stability of the ICW catalysts tested in the PDH reaction with pure propane at a WHSV of 3.5 h−1, their specific activities, ranging from 0.36 to 0.41 s−1, were somewhat lower than those of highly dispersed Pt0Znδ+/SiO2 catalysts, which achieved 0.96 s−1 using a surface organometallic chemistry approach [41]. This performance was also lower than that of the single-atom catalyst 0.1Pt10Cu/Al2O3, with 0.98 s−1 [42], and the PtLa/mz-deGa catalyst, with 0.57 s−1 [43]. However, by increasing the WHSV, ICW catalysts can achieve higher specific activity. For instance, the specific activity of the (3NaSn)(Pt)w catalyst (sample 8) reached 2.26 s−1 at a WHSV of 28 h−1. The introduction of Pt into samples 6–9 was conducted after the acid sites had been neutralized, suggesting that these suppressed sites likely did not influence the distribution of Pt. Nonetheless, the initial acidity of the zeolite markedly impacts its catalytic properties. To elucidate this effect, four (3NaSn)(Pt)w catalysts, each with varying SiO2/Al2O3 ratios, were prepared, as shown in Fig. 2a. Notably, the total acidity of initial zeolites decreases with increasing SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio. According to both NH3-TPD and Py-IR data (Figs. S2 and S3), the total acidity varies distinctly from the number of Brønsted acid sites (BAS) on the outer surface of these samples, which decreases in a different order: MFI-80 > MFI-50 > MFI-280 > MFI-716. It should be noted that the external acidity of the initial zeolites is more than 10 times lower than their total acidity (Table S1). At WHSV of 3.5 h −1 , the variation in specific activities of the (3NaSn)(Pt)w samples, derived from zeolites with SiO2/Al2O3 ratios ranging from 50 to 716, was not substantial, showing values between 0.34 and 0.42 s−1. However, in the PDH reaction, the deactivation constants were significantly lower (indicating higher stability) for zeolites with SiO2/Al2O3 ratios of 50 and 80, compared to those with ratios of 280 and 716, as shown in Fig. 2a. Furthermore, the deactivation constants decreased as the concentration of acid sites on the outer surface increased (Fig. 2b). This can be attributed to the involvement of zeolite acid sites in influencing the distribution of tin and platinum during catalyst preparation and in maintaining PtSn nanoparticles during the reaction. To verify this, four (Pt) samples with varying SiO2/Al2O3 ratios were synthesized. Pt dispersion, as measured by CO chemisorption analysis, increased with the rise in the acidity of the outer surface (Fig. 2b). This phenomenon can be elucidated by the stabilization of Pt through interaction with a Brønsted proton and an adjacent framework oxygen [44]. This finding further confirms that the outer surface acidity of MFI-type zeolites plays an important role in catalytic performance. It aligns with our previous studies conducted on catalysts without Sn [36]. To further investigate the impact of zeolite acidity on the catalytic characteristics of ICW catalysts, we compared a series of samples derived from MFI-80 and MFI-716 at a propane WHSV of 28 h −1 ( Fig. 3a and b). The (3Na)(Pt)w and (3NaSn)(Pt)w samples, when prepared using zeolite MFI-80, exhibited greater activity and stability compared to those derived from MFI-716. In addition, samples based on MFI-80 demonstrated superior selectivity to propylene over those based on MFI-716. When MFI-type zeolite is impregnated with platinum, the large hexachloroplatinate ions cannot penetrate the pores, primarily remaining on the external surface. Thus, the outer surface’s acidity is important crucial for improved dispersion. Indeed, CO chemisorption data reveal that the Pt dispersion in the (Pt) and (PtSn) samples, derived from MFI-80 zeolite, is significantly higher than those from the MFI-716 zeolite, which has a lower acid site concentration (Fig. 3c). This difference further underscores the role of acid sites in Pt distribution. Notably, with a bulk Pt concentration of 0.5 wt%, the Pt/BAS molar ratio on the external surface of MFI-80 zeolite is 3.4, in contrast to 52 for the MFI-716 (Table S1). During the preparation of (3Na)(Pt)w samples, Pt was introduced into a zeolite with pre-neutralized acidity. Even in this scenario, high dispersion values of approximately 20% were observed, indicating that the excess of NaCl also contributes to Pt spreading. The incorporation of Sn leads to a marked reduction in Pt dispersion values, as indicated by CO chemisorption data. This reduction could be due to blocking a significant portion of platinum during the formation of PtSn nanoparticles, altering the electronic properties of platinum when in contact with tin, which inhibits Pt’s interaction with CO [45], or a combination of these factors. Therefore, this method may not be sufficiently reliable for determining Pt dispersion in the presence of Sn. However, quantitative values can be effectively compared within a series of identical catalysts. The catalytic properties of the (3Na)(Pt)w and (3NaSn)(Pt)w samples provide compelling evidence that the inclusion of Sn significantly enhances all catalytic characteristics. It is commonly believed that the addition of Sn improves the catalytic properties of platinum catalysts by altering the electronic and geometric structure of Pt sites [8,46]. With the presence of tin in PtSn particles, platinum’s interaction with hydrocarbons is markedly weakened, resulting in reduced coke formation. The presence of tin atoms disrupts the proximity of platinum atoms, thus improving Pt dispersion and resistance to sintering while diminishing the breaking of C–C and C–H bonds [47]. When tin is uniformly distributed on the substrate surface before the addition of Pt, PtSn catalysts with enhanced characteristics are produced [48,49]. For effective Sn distribution, it is beneficial to use the acidic sites of the zeolite and an excess amount of NaCl. Table 1 shows examples of cases where the zeolite was initially co-impregnated with NaCl and SnCl2. Following calcination in air, Sn was uniformly immobilized on the zeolite surface ( Fig. 4). The Sn quantity remained consistent after washing with water. XPS spectra confirmed that in the air-calcined (3NaSn)(Pt)w sample with 0.45% Sn, Sn existed only in its oxidized states, Sn(II) and Sn(IV), as shown in Fig. S4. The similar area of the high-temperature peak in the NH3-TPD curve indicates that Sn is not localized in the ion-exchange positions. Simultaneously, there is an observed increase in the low-temperature peak, ascribable to an increase in the number of weak Lewis acid sites associated with tin oxide (Fig. S5). Notably, unlike the samples (Pt) and (2.1NaPt) containing more than 60% Pt in the form of Pt0 [36], Pt in (3NaSn)(Pt)w primarily exists in the oxidized states of Pt2+ and Pt4+ after being calcined in air at 500 °C (Fig. S6). The impact of Sn on the oxidative state of Pt could be attributed to the reduction in the size of Pt particles, leading to an increased ability to oxidize when calcined in air. In contrast to the CO chemisorption data, the high dispersion of Pt on Sn-containing samples is evidenced by TEM analysis. This method shows a uniform distribution of Pt and other components on the zeolite surface, with an average particle diameter of 1.2 nm, as observed in the (3NaSn)(Pt)w catalyst (Fig. 4). Furthermore, no significant variation in Pt particle sizes is noted in the STEM images of the (3NaSn)(Pt)w sample, both before and after washing (Fig. S7). TEM findings for the (3NaSn)(Pt)w catalyst indicate that 95% of Pt particles are up to 1.4 nm in diameter, with a density of 7.7 particles per 100 nm2, which is 1.4 times greater than in a similar sample without Sn [36]. The increased count of smaller particles implies Sn’s role in enhancing Pt dispersion [47]. The enhancement of Pt dispersion with the addition of Sn is corroborated by both XRD analysis and IR-CO experiments. For the IWI sample containing only Pt, derived from impregnating MFI-80 zeolite with H2PtCl6, a distinct Pt reflection appears at 39.8°. However, in the XRD patterns of the (3NaSn)(Pt)w sample, prepared using the ICW method, neither Pt nor NaCl phases are detectable (Fig. S8). Furthermore, the IR-CO experiment reveals a notable increase in intensity at 2063 cm−1, corresponding to the linearly bonded CO on Pt atoms in the (3NaSn)(Pt)w sample compared with the (Pt) sample (Fig. S9). 3.2 Influence of the sequence of preparation steps When choosing the order in which components should be introduced in the synthesis of PtSn catalysts, it is crucial to consider various factors, such as the ease of Sn salt hydrolysis, the interaction of Sn2+ complexes with H2PtCl6 in water, and the need to suppress zeolite acid sites. The significance of the component deposition sequence is exemplified in the preparation of (2NaPt)w(Sn). Assuming that adding Sn to the already active and stable (2NaPt)w catalyst obtained by the ICW method [36] would enhance its properties seems logical. However, while Sn addition improved the propylene selectivity, it reduced the activity and stability of the (2NaPt)w(Sn) catalyst (Fig. S10). Table 2 provides catalytic data for various ICW catalysts prepared using different sequences of Pt, Sn, Na addition, and excess NaCl removal. Although this list is not exhaustive, it sufficiently illustrates the impact of the preparation sequence on the catalysts’ properties. The sequence of both the metal introduction and washing stages significantly affects the ICW catalysts’ characteristics. At a WHSV of 3.5 h −1 , the specific activities of the samples in Table 2 show no dramatic differences. The primary distinction in the catalytic behavior lies in the stability of the samples. Based on the deactivation constants, samples 8 and 10–19 can be categorized into three groups: 1) The stable ones with Kd of 0.003–0.006 h−1, 2) catalysts with moderate stability with Kd of 0.009–0.015 h−1, and 3) the unstable samples with Kd of 0.049–0.058 h−1. Unstable catalysts, specifically samples 14 and 15, were prepared by introducing Sn after Pt. HCl was added to the impregnation solution to inhibit SnCl2 hydrolysis, leading to a partial ion exchange of Na+ with H+ ions. Consequently, the catalyst (3NaPt)w(Sn) became more acidic, resulting in lower propylene selectivity and higher coke formation. In the case of another unstable catalyst, (Pt)(Sn3Na)w, the SnCl2 impregnation solution contained both HCl and NaCl. Although NaCl partially reduces zeolite acidity during subsequent calcination, enhancing propylene selectivity, this neutralization is not sufficient to boost stability. Furthermore, the low stability of both catalysts appears to be due to Sn atoms covering the existing Pt particles, which reduces the number of available Pt sites for the PDH reaction. The earlier observation highlighted that adding an Sn precursor to zeolite in the presence of HCl at the final stage resulted in an undesirable increase in the catalyst’s acidity. This issue can be resolved by rinsing away excess NaCl following the introduction and calcination of Sn. Consequently, the catalyst (3NaPt)(Sn)w (sample 13), prepared using this method, demonstrated significantly improved stability and selectivity compared to the (3NaPt)w(Sn) catalyst (sample 14). This instance underscores the critical role of the washing step in the sequence of ICW catalyst preparation. Introducing Na (in samples 11 and 12) or Sn alone (in samples 16 and 17) during the initial stage of preparation led to catalysts with moderate stability. When Na is used, improved stability is attained due to the co-impregnation of Pt and Sn. However, this process introduces metals into the zeolite while neutralizing its acidity. Conversely, when using Sn, the zeolite’s acid sites participate in dispersing Pt and Sn. However, this might result in less uniform PtSn particle formation, as Sn and Pt are introduced separately. When a zeolite with non-neutralized acidity is co-impregnated with Pt and Sn (samples 18 and 19), the dispersion and stability of Pt are higher than those of NaCl-containing zeolite co-impregnation (samples 11, 12). This suggests that the acidic sites of zeolite significantly influence the dispersion of catalyst components. Superior catalyst performance was noted in zeolites co-impregnated first either with Na and Sn (samples 8 and 10), or with Pt and Sn (sample 18). Sample 19, prepared by co-impregnating all components simultaneously, met both criteria and consequently demonstrated remarkable catalytic characteristics. The distinction between the samples (3NaSn)(Pt)w and (3NaSn)w(Pt) (8 and 10) lies in the extent of NaCl excess during Pt impregnation into the zeolite: substantial for sample 8 and minor for sample 10. Before washing, the Na/Pt atomic ratio in the (3NaSn)(Pt) sample was approximately 50, compared to approximately 5 in the (3NaSn)w(Pt) sample. The improved Pt dispersion and the excellent stability of the (3NaSn)(Pt)w and (3NaSn)w(Pt) catalysts may be attributed to the dilution of SnCl2 with NaCl during their co-impregnation, the influence of finely dispersed Sn’s geometric effect and the dilution of H2PtCl6 with NaCl during H2PtCl6 impregnation, and Pt redistribution in the washing process. Therefore, the sequence of preparation steps is crucial for determining metal distribution, catalyst acidity, and, ultimately, catalytic performance. To develop an effective PtSn ICW catalyst for the PDH reaction, it is recommended to disperse tin on the zeolite surface evenly, either before or simultaneously with Pt introduction. 3.3 Influence of washing In the ICW method, the excess acidity-neutralizing agent must be washed off with water. Observations [36] have shown that in addition to eliminating excess NaCl, redistribution of Pt species can also occur during the washing process. Regardless of the initial NaCl loading, a certain amount of Na remains in the catalysts after a single washing procedure. The majority of this remaining Na exists as cations in ion-exchange positions, with a minor portion in the form of NaCl. Excess NaCl is known to adversely affect the catalytic properties of PDH catalysts. The residual excess appears negligible after a single wash. However, additional washing impacts the Pt dispersion and stability ( Table 3). The pre-catalyst (3NaSn)(Pt) was washed with five times the amount of water, conducted once or twice. This double washing increased the Pt dispersion from 12% in the (3NaSn)(Pt)w catalyst to 20% in the (3NaSn)(Pt)ww catalyst, maintaining the same Pt content. In addition, there was an increase in the catalyst’s specific activity from 2.26 to 2.46 s−1 and a slight decrease in initial selectivity, as seen in Fig. 5. Two series of ICW catalysts were compared to investigate the impact of washing. In both series, tin was introduced and dispersed via co-impregnation with NaCl and Sn (II) chloride. The distinction between these series lies in the placement of the washing procedure within the sequence of preparation steps. For the first series (Tables 1 and 3, samples 8 and 20–22), excess NaCl was washed out following the introduction of platinum. Conversely, for the second series (samples 10, 23–26), the excess NaCl was removed before this step. To assess the effect of completely removing excess sodium cations on the platinum dispersion and catalytic properties of the samples, repeated washing was performed. Catalysts from both series demonstrated high specific activity, with values ranging from 2.2–2.5 s−1 for those containing 0.44–0.46 wt% Pt, and 3.7 to 5.2 s−1 for samples with 0.21–0.28 wt% Pt. The stability and Pt dispersion of the first series of catalysts, with postadditional washing, are notably superior to those of similar catalysts from the second series, as evidenced in comparisons such as samples 20 vs 23 or 22 vs 25. Additional washing left the selectivity toward propylene unchanged; however, it resulted in a modest increase in the formation of heavier hydrocarbons, attributed to the release of some acidic sites, as opposed to the results of a single wash. In catalysts from the first series, the Pt dispersion is significantly enhanced following additional washing. It is presumed that the residual 0.1–0.3 wt% NaCl, remaining after the initial wash, impedes propane’s access to the Pt centers. Subsequent to the additional washing, a considerably larger fraction of Pt becomes accessible, leading to a 1.5–2-fold increase in dispersion. In contrast, the second series demonstrates an opposite trend. Enhanced removal of NaCl results in the introduction of Pt proceeding in the absence of both acidic sites and excess NaCl. This process deteriorates the interaction between Pt and the zeolite, compounded by a deficiency of dispersant, resulting in suboptimal Pt distribution on the surface. Consequently, the additional washing in the second series reduces the Pt dispersion and catalyst stability. If the (3NaSn)w(0.25Pt) catalyst (sample 24) is further washed with water, the Pt dispersion and stability of the resulting catalyst (sample 26) decrease by a factor of two, while the initial activity and selectivity to propylene are preserved. This suggests that the presence of merely 0.1–0.3 wt% excess Na relative to the zeolite acid sites is sufficient to maintain stable operation and Pt dispersion. 3.4 Influence of Sn/Pt atomic ratio According to current understanding, structure-insensitive dehydrogenation reactions are generally catalyzed effectively by a small ensemble of platinum sites [48]. As the size of Pt clusters decreases, propane conversion tends to increase, whereas selectivity toward propylene demonstrates an opposite trend [50]. It is reasonable to assume that reducing the Pt content leads to a smaller size of Pt particles and a higher specific activity [7]. The (3NaSn)(0.25Pt)w catalyst, with a lower Pt content, exhibited a propane conversion similar to the (3NaSn)(0.5Pt)w sample. This indicates a 2-fold increase in specific activity, as seen in samples 21 and 8 (Table 3). A high specific activity of 6.7 s−1 was achieved for the (3NaSn)(0.1Pt)w catalyst, containing 0.1 wt% Pt, although it demonstrated reduced stability (Table S2). However, the Pt dispersion (measured by CO chemisorption) for sample 21 is lower than for sample 8. In contrast, the second series showed that Pt dispersion increased with Pt content (samples 10 vs 24, 23 vs 25, Table 3). This apparent contradiction might be due to an increase in the Sn/Pt atomic ratio when the platinum amount is reduced. When the tin content in the samples is decreased, Pt dispersion increases again as the platinum content decreases. For example, the Pt dispersion for sample (3Na0.5Sn)(0.5Pt)w, with a Sn/Pt atomic ratio of 0.9, is 10%, while for sample (3Na0.5Sn)(0.25Pt)w, with a Sn/Pt atomic ratio of 1.8, it is 26% (Table S2). Fig. 6 illustrates that elevating the Sn/Pt atomic ratio results in diminished catalyst stability. Notably, the deactivation constant for a comparable sample without tin is measured at 0.286 h−1. This observation corroborates previous studies indicating that a heightened Sn/Pt ratio reduces both the activity and stability of SnPt catalysts. This decline is attributed to the increased formation of Sn(0) and PtSn, which are tin-rich alloys [32,51]. The optimal Sn amount varies significantly, depending on the method used to obtain PtSn nanoparticles and the type of support material. For PtSn/ZSM-5 [32], Pt/Sn2.00-Beta [49], Pt–Sn-6/MgAl2O4 [52], and Pt/MgAl(Sn)Ox [51] catalysts, the best performances were observed with Sn/Pt ratios of 5, 2, 2, and 1–2, respectively. ICW catalysts show improved stability at an Sn/Pt ratio of 1–2, as indicated in Fig. 6 and Table S2. 3.5 Long-term stability and regeneration Long-term stability is crucial for the practical application of Pt-based catalysts. Two catalysts, (3NaSn)(Pt)ww and (3NaSn)(0.25Pt)ww, were tested in a 25-h reaction run. These catalysts exhibited stable operation at 570 °C and a WHSV of 28 h−1. Initial propane conversions for these samples were 36% and 32%, respectively, with propylene selectivity for both catalysts at approximately 96%. Specific activities were 2.84 s−1 and 5.33 s−1, respectively ( Fig. 7). The sample with higher Pt content showed marginally greater stability; deactivation constants for (3NaSn)(Pt)ww and (3NaSn)(0.25Pt)ww catalysts were 0.009 and 0.016 h−1, respectively. Notably, the amount of coke formed appeared to be proportional to the Pt content. Specifically, 1.19 wt% of coke was found in the (3NaSn)(Pt)ww catalyst, while 0.66 wt% was formed in the (3NaSn)(0.25Pt)ww catalyst. The regenerative capability of the catalyst was evaluated using the (3NaSn)(Pt)w sample. It underwent oxidative regeneration in air at 500 °C and subsequent reduction in hydrogen at 570 °C, maintaining high activity and selectivity. To evaluate the (3NaSn)(Pt)w ICW catalyst’s performance, three reaction/regeneration cycles were conducted. Fig. 8 shows the catalyst nearly fully regained its activity after each cycle, with selectivity to propylene ranging between 96% and 97%. The initial propane conversions remained consistent across cycles. However, the catalyst’s stability showed a slight decline with each cycle. This observation implies that the reduction in catalytic activity was not solely due to carbon deposition on the catalyst’s surface but also to the sintering of metal particles (Fig. S11). Although carbon deposits can be completely eliminated through oxidation, the metal particle sintering process is irreversible. 3.6 ICW method features Table 4 summarizes the positive and negative impacts of various factors on the formation of the active site during the preparation of the PtSn/MFI catalysts using the ICW method. The literature extensively reported the role of Pt as a dehydrogenating metal and Sn as a promoter. These roles are further confirmed in this study through the synthesis and catalytic evaluation of PtSn/MFI catalysts employing the ICW method. These factors, which act in different directions, necessitate a careful balance to achieve a highly active and stable catalyst. This balance is attainable by optimizing several key parameters: Pt content, the Na/Pt and Sn/Pt ratios, the order of metal introduction, and thorough washing to remove excess NaCl with water. Table 5 lists the recent PtSn/MFI catalysts for the PDH reaction. Comparing Pt PDH catalysts described in the literature is often challenging due to the wide range of reaction conditions. As an illustration, we examined the (1.8NaSn)(Pt)w catalyst in PDH reactions at 570 °C, 0.1 MPa, WHSV= 14 h−1, using different feed gas compositions (Fig. S12). Variations in stability, specific activities, and coke accumulation were observed when performing PDH reactions with pure propane as compared to propane mixtures containing nitrogen or hydrogen. We suggest using the catalyst index of productivity (IP) as a benchmark for comparison, which is calculated as follows: IP = SA Kd * 3600 , where. SA - specific activity expressed in s−1;. Kd - deactivation constant expressed in h−1;. 3600 - the number of seconds in an hour. The catalyst’s performance improves with a higher IP. Although the IP parameter is partially affected by the PDH reaction conditions, it serves as an effective measure of the catalyst’s efficiency. The MFI-80-based catalysts prepared through the ICW method have shown some of the best operational characteristics among the known PtSn/MFI catalysts despite being produced using very simple and well-established techniques, including impregnation, calcination, and water washing. 4 Conclusions The ICW method was successfully used in the preparation of PtSn/MFI catalysts. This technique enables precise control of the dispersion of platinum and tin, as well as their interaction, leading to the formation of fine PtSn particles. The excellent stability of the PtSn/MFI ICW catalysts is attributed to the extensive use of NaCl in the impregnation process, which enhances the dispersion of Sn and Pt. In addition, washing the calcined Sn and Pt-containing catalyst precursors helps remove NaCl and redistribute the metals. The ICW method of catalyst synthesis makes use of surface acidic sites to achieve a uniform distribution of active components. Moreover, the ICW method helps neutralize this acidity, thus reducing the likelihood of undesired side reactions. This study demonstrated that active, selective, and highly stable PDH catalysts can be synthesized using common commercial zeolites with an MFI structure despite their significant acidity. coredata.dc:description: A simple and scalable impregnation–calcination–washing (ICW) method has been proposed for synthesizing PtSn/MFI catalysts. This study primarily investigates the impact of zeolite acidity, the order of preparation steps, and the influence of tin, NaCl, and water washing on the characteristics of ICW propane dehydrogenation catalysts. To improve the dispersion of Pt and Sn, a zeolite characterized by high external surface acidity was used as a support. In addition, a significant quantity of NaCl was employed during the impregnation process. Washing the zeolite surface to remove excess NaCl releases active sites and redistributes Pt. This preparation procedure resulted in the formation of highly active and stable propane dehydrogenation catalysts. The most efficient PtSn/MFI ICW catalyst exhibited an initial propane conversion of 36%, propylene selectivity of 96%, and a deactivation constant of 0.009 h−1 at 570 °C, with a weight hourly space velocity of 28 h−1.
coredata.dc:title: PtSn/MFI catalysts for propane dehydrogenation prepared by an impregnation–calcination–washing method
